posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked:
We are using YAGSL for a kraken swerve drive, but due to this being the first year we used yagsl we copy and pasted most of our code, and we cannot figure out how to turn our code into robot relative. our code just asks for controller inputs and it makes the library do the rest it seems like. i will link our code here, any question i can respond to.

Robot Container

Swerve Subsystem

As you can see, we have the methods for it in the swerve subsystem, but due to how we control it in robot container using the swerve input stream of mystery, im not sure how to make a button/trigger cause it to use robot oriented while held. Link to the github for more detail

Bonus details: we want to be able to rotate the robot to certain headings, but due to the PID loop we use, we believe it stops before it gets there due to the deadzone and that is why it isnt working. to rotate the robot, we are changing the values in the right stick of the controller to make it think i am manually turning it. Is there a way to turn all of this into a drive method so that we can rotate the robot without worrying about deadzones sometimes maybe?

When you have a problem with field oriented; you will probably have a problem during auto.

You can ignore this by switching to robot oriented like you said. To do this just pass the swerve input stream into a drive function which takes the Supplier<ChassisSpeeds> as the input stream. Then pass the chassisspeeds to Swervezdrive.drive

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: but how can i toggle between the two while i hold a button?

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: bump
The .drive method has a boolean flag for field oriented. You could use that with a boolean toggled by a controller button to change it if you REALLY want to.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
If you have an Xbox style controller (two analog sticks and a D-pad), consider having the D-pad be robot relative and slow and the left stick being field relative and the right stick being rotation.

We found that to be a nice, flexible approach for our drivers and it’s very hard for them to get confused about what mode the robot is in (because it’s two different controls rather than one control with two modes).

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: it has a flag for robot oriented, does that mean it is field oriented by default

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: i have these two velocities, but how can i toggle which command i am using when i press a button? please help

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
The easiest command-oriented way is something like this, and then pick up the flag for your drive command as noted previously.

This runs that command when the driver presses the button, and turns it off when they press it again. You can also combine exit conditions and booleans with with ConditionalCommand to form toggles.

That said, toggles tend to be extremely problematic for drivers, so I’d recommend against that. The short form is that it forces them to mentally track the robot state, and an errant button press now forces them to debug what could be wrong in real time, find the state trigger, and hit it again. And hit it exactly once, or they put it back on accident, which is a common pitfall of toggles.

Generally, it’s much more reliable to these drive overrides active only while holding a button, and automatically exiting when the button is released. This gives your drivers “stateless” control of the robot, and it always reacts the same way based on the buttons they’re pressing, rather than the order in which they pressed them.

Normally, if a “toggle” comes up in our discussion, it means we’re fundamentally misunderstanding something about what our driver wants, or some other missed detail about how the robot is reacting.

In this case, it sounds like you’re just undershooting, so you might consider other options such as

Increase the specificity of your exit conditions, such as checking both proximity to your goal, and the speed when you get there.

Increasing your settle time using a .debounce() on the trigger that ends a sequence

Add an additional command to that sequence that just runs it with a small timeout, possibly with higher PID gains (we did this, worked great).

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: sorry i phrased wrong, its not a toggle, it uses robot oriented driving on the joysticks while i hold a button, and field when i dont hold it

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: when i pressed the button to change the robotRelative() flag, the robot code went red on driver station

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Check your stack trace in the Riolog: It’ll point you to the line of code where things went wrong.

More than likely, something wasn’t defined and was left as “null”, rather than true or false.

However, depending on your code you might have done something else, such as reused a command assigned to a variable in multiple command structures (which they do not like).

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: we have a meeting in an hour where i can test it the final meeting before comp, is there another place i can contact you where you would be able to see myy response quicklyy?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: Not especially, but I’ll keep the thread open in case I’m lurking around here then.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Plenty of eyes will see it here and we all want you to get onto the field with a working bot.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
In the good news side of things: I grabbed your code, ran it in sim, no crashes.

Adding the following line in the controller bindings new Trigger(driverController::getAButton).whileTrue(driveRobotOriented); got it working as intended: While holding A, it correctly swaps from field to robot oriented driving. So, nothing seems fundamentally wrong with what you’re doing, you likely just had a stray bug somewhere.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
For completeness, I suspect i found your bug, which likely stemmed from using swerveInputStream like so

which yielded

Your existing workarounds (as tested above) work fine, so maybe just go with that if you’ve sorted it out, since I think that’ll be easier to dodge controller inversion issues. But, if you wanted to fix this easily, you could always just turn off alliance control using the same button that enables robotRelative, like so:

In other news, I’m glad I helped with this, since this SwerveInputStream class is stellar. Not sure how my crew missed it.

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: awesome, ill use this and test it out in the pits tomorrow! (we dont have sim setup yet )

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
You actually kinda do. Yagsl ships with simulation by default, and publishes a Field2d that shows the robot position, simulation position, and module info. This is how I was able to test things in your code. You can view it in the Simulation dashboard under the Networktables > Smartdashboard > Field.

Using a real driverstation or the simulation joystick configuration, you can then drive around on that little field to test things out.
Expanding on @tekdemo excellent answers we even made videos on it!
